Who knows we may find more but Semerkhet' is right on the edge of historical oblivion which gives me a chance to post one of my favorite poems . It deals with the once all powerful king of kings ruler of a vast domain who built spectacular monuments to himself but is now forgotten. There are two versions of the poem one by Shelley is far and away the more famous , even used on breaking bad but who remembers Horace smith? He wrote a good version . Smith and Sheley were friends and the poems were written as a competition . So when we are talking about the march of time and eventual oblivion I think the “forgotten” version makes the point better IN Egypt’s sandy silence, all alone,Stands a gigantic Leg, which far off throwsThe only shadow that the Desert knows:—“I am great OZYMANDIAS,” saith the stone,“The King of Kings; this mighty City shows“The wonders of my hand.”— The City’s gone,—Nought but the Leg remaining to discloseThe site of this forgotten Babylon. We wonder,—and some Hunter may expressWonder like ours, when thro’ the wildernessWhere London stood, holding the Wolf in chase,He meets some fragment huge, and stops to guessWhat powerful but unrecorded raceOnce dwelt in that annihilated place.–
